[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-service/src/error.rs] [Enum: Error] [Information Disclosure] Do the InternalError and SerializationError variants leak sensitive internal implementation details about execution state, validator configurations, or cryptographic operations through their String payloads that could be exploited by Byzantine validators to fingerprint node implementations? [File: aptos-core/execution/executor-service/src/error.rs] [Enum: Error] [Information Disclosure] Does the SerializationError(String) variant expose details about the internal structure of RemoteExecutionRequest or RemoteExecutionResult that could be exploited to craft malicious payloads bypassing validation in remote executor clients? [File: aptos-core/execution/executor-service/src/error.rs] [Enum: Error] [Consensus Attack] Can a malicious coordinator exploit error message patterns in InternalError to determine which shards are processing specific transactions, enabling targeted attacks on cross-shard transaction execution to cause state inconsistencies? [File: aptos-core/execution/executor-service/src/error.rs] [Enum: Error] [Error Masking] Does the generic InternalError variant mask critical security-relevant errors (e.g., signature validation failures, merkle proof mismatches, or consensus violations) making it impossible to properly audit security incidents in sharded execution? [File: aptos-core/execution/executor-service/src/error.rs] [Enum: Error] [Serialization] Does the Serialize/Deserialize implementation for the Error enum properly validate the String payloads during deserialization, or can malformed strings cause panics or undefined behavior in receiving nodes?
